benchmark_details.name: Interpolated Approximate Measurement (IAM)
benchmark_details.overview: IAM quantifies sample-level unlearning completeness by interpolating the model’s generalization-fitting behavior gap on queried samples, revealing risks of both over-unlearning and under-unlearning in approximate unlearning systems.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To measure sample-level unlearning completeness and identify unlearning risks in machine learning models, particularly in approximate unlearning settings.

data.source: CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, CINIC-10, and Purchase datasets; also applicable to LLaMA-2 models.
data.size: 197,324 records for Purchase; 60,000 images for CIFAR datasets; 270,000 images for CINIC-10.

methods: Computed CDF values for the membership scores
Used weighted averaging for interpolation results
methodology.calculation: Combined scores from interpolated estimates and shadow models to calculate membership scores indicating unlearning completeness.
methodology.interpretation: A membership score of 0 indicates that the model’s response relies entirely on generalization ability, while a score closer to 1 indicates fitting behavior.
methodology.baseline_results: Existing Membership Inference Attack methods were benchmarked against IAM.
methodology.validation: Evaluated across various datasets and approximating unlearning algorithms.

targeted_risks.harm: Identified unlearning risks including under-unlearning (incomplete removal of data influence) and over-unlearning (removal of useful data influence).

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: All data used are publicly available; no personal information involved.
